field_edited_text.value:
20 SUSQUEHANNA RIVER BRIDGE

advisability of using piers extending to rock except in the case of piers where
rock is excessively deep and pile foundations have been adopted. The
borings were made by driving a pipe casing to rock, removing the material
in the casing by jetting, sampling and recording the strata through which
the casing was driven, and by core drilling the bed rock a depth of 15 feet
in a majority of the holes, with 1 inch diameter diamond drills to insure
reaching solid rock and not thin ledges or boulders

The character of the rock and of the strata overlying the rock at the site
of this bridge indicates that piers can be constructed by well proven methods
involving no special difficulties.

FOUNDATIONS

After studying various methods for building the foundations for this
bridge, it was decided to use open cofferdam methods for removing the over-
burden on the rock at the site of piers to be founded on rock. The estimates
of pier costs hereinafter presented are based on the use of cofferdams, in
order that the rock foundations may be cleaned off, roughly benched, leveled
and inspected and the concrete foundations for the piers poured directly on
the prepared rock surface. Cofferdams instead of caissons seem to meet the
conditions, because the rock surface is expected to be very irregular. Such
irregularities would cause possible extra cost and delay in case caissons were
used. Due allowance has also been made in the estimates for grouting
seams and fissures. Out-crops in this granite elsewhere indicate that seams
and fissures are to be expected. It has been decided to protect the con-
crete of the river piers at the water line by band courses of rock faced granite
ashlar masonry to protect the piers against the severe ice conditions oc-
casionally occurring in the Susquehanna River. This decision was partially
influenced by the available granite quarries in the vicinity.

Where rock was found to be excessively deep, it was decided to use steel
pile foundations. Since the steel piles for these piers after being driven will
be fully supported for their full length, and will be driven to rock for end
bearing, they have been designed to carry a maximum load of 108 tons.
The capping of the piles and the construction of the remaining portions of
these pile piers will be done in a manner similar to that above deseribed for
foundations on rock, and in accordance with the plans for the piers, as shown
on Plates 12 and 13, “Typical Piers” and ‘“Typical River Piers.”

For purposes of illustration, following are Figures 2 and 3, Typical Piers
supported on rock and on steel piles, accompanied by typical design com-
putations for the two types. ;
